questions.text: What is the accommodative amplitude of a patient with a near point at 20 cm and a far point at infinity?
questions.solution:
The amplitude of accommodation for the above patient would be 5 dioptres.

Near point of accommodation (NPA) is the closest distance at which the near object is clearly focussed without blur.

Amplitude of accommodation is the maximum power of the lens that permits clear near vision without blur. Its unit is dioptre (D). The amplitude of accommodation is the reciprocal of near point of accommodation (NPA) in meters.

20 cm is 1/5th of a metre. Therefore, the accommodative amplitude is its inverse, that is, 5D.

Note:

The NPA is measured clinically using a scale device such as the Prince, Berens, or Royal Air Force (RAF) ruler.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Bowen’s disease?
questions.solution:
Bowen's disease has a low potential for invasive malignancy. 

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it.

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is false according to Caldwell and Moloy classification of pelvis:

choices.text: Platypelloid pelvis: has AP diameter > transverse diameter
Gynecoid pelvis:  sacral angle greater than 90 degree
Anthropoid pelvis: high incidence of face to pubis delivery

questions.solution:
Platypelloid pelvis has a transverse diameter much larger than the anteroposterior diameter.

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Shape  Round  Anteroposteriorlyoval  Triangular/ Heart shaped  Transversely oval /Flat bowl 
Sacrum  Sacral angle (SA)more than 90°  SA more than 90° Sacral angle lessthan 90° SA more than 90°
Sidewalls  Straight or slightlydivergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (morethan 90°) 
Position  Occipitolateral or oblique occipitoanterior  Direct occipitoanteriororposterior  Occipitolateral oroblique occipitoposterior  Occipitolateral 
Diameter of engagement  Transverse oroblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse oroblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   More incidenceof face-to-pubisdelivery  a/w deep transverse arrest.Difficult delivery with increased chance of perineal injuries  No difficulty

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

Kasai procedure:

questions.text: A 45-year-old  chronic alcoholic with liver disease came to the hospital with complaints of distension of the abdomen. On per abdominal examination shifting dullness was positive. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the positive shifting dullness indicate ascites probably due to liver cirrhosis in alcoholic liver disease. Spironolactone is used in the treatment of ascites due to cirrhosis. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Furosemide may be added particularly in patients of ascites who have peripheral edema and non responsive to spironolactone.

questions.text: The image given below is used for the depiction of _______ of a disease in epidemiology.
questions.solution:
Spot maps are used to understand the local distributions of a disease.

Spot maps:

  • They are also called shaded maps.
  • They depict areas of high or low frequency, the boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution.
  • This method was used by John Snow to investigate the epidemic of cholera in London in 1854.

questions.text: A patient, known case of osteoarthritis is keen on taking the Kellgren and Lawrence scoring test. This scoring system is based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Kellgren and Lawrence scoring system uses radiographic changes (X-rays) to divide OA into five categories.

It is the most commonly used system.

  • Grade 0: no radiographic features of OA are present
  • Grade 1: doubtful joint space narrowing (JSN) and possible osteophytic lipping
  • Grade 2: definite osteophytes and possible JSN on anteroposterior weight-bearing radiograph
  • Grade 3: multiple osteophytes, definite JSN, sclerosis, possible bony deformity
  • Grade 4: large osteophytes, marked JSN, severe sclerosis and definite bony deformity 

Other radiological classification systems include Ahlbäck radiographic classification for knee OA.

The Outerbridge classification is based on cartilage damage as observed by arthroscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of levator ani?
questions.solution:
Ischiococcygeus is not a part of levator ani muscle.

Ischiococcygeus (coccygeus) is a separate muscle, and lies at the posterosuperior part of the levator ani.

The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:

  • Pubococcygeus
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

The pelvic floor has two hiatuses:

  • The urogenital hiatus – An anteriorly situated gap, which allows passage of the urethra (and the vagina in females).
  • The rectal hiatus – A centrally positioned gap, which allows passage of the anal canal.

questions.text: The image given below represents ______
questions.solution:
Image shows eliciting "Homan’s sign" i.e. calf tenderness on forced ankle dorsiflexion seen in DVT(deep venous thrombosis)

Other signs are:

  • Moses Sign - Calf tenderness on direct pressure on calf.
  • Pratt’s Sign - Calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.solution:
The curare notch in the plateau phase of the capnograph indicates that the patient is trying to breathe spontaneously. The patient's inspiratory effort causes some fresh gas to be sucked in the capnometer, resulting in a lower carbon dioxide concentration and a notch.

Image below shows a capnograph with clefts during phase III which indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation. It is also known as a curare notch or cleft.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following GAG is responsible for the charge selectiveness of the renal glomerular basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Heparan sulfate is the GAG involved in the charge selectiveness of renal glomerular basement membrane.

Heparan sulfate is a GAG made up of repeating units of glucosamine and glucuronic acid.

Functions:

  • Mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication by acting as receptors on the cell membrane
  • Charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration: Since heparan sulfate contains a lot of negative charges, its ability to repel proteins is important in glomerular filtration.
  • Lipoprotein lipase is anchored by heparan sulfate.

Note : 

  • The only intracellular GAG is heparin.

Related Pearl: Biologically important Glycosoaminoglycans(GAG's)

GAG Disaccharide repeat units
Keratan sulfate N Acetyl Glucosamine +Galactose
Hyaluronic acid N Acetyl Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid
Chondroitin sulfate N Acetyl Galactosamine + Glucuronic acid
Dermatan Sulfate N Acetyl Galactosamine + Iduronic/ Glucuronic acid
Heparan sulfate Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid
Heparin Glucosamine + Iduronic acid

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

CP is a static encephalopathy and a disorder of posture and movement often associated with:

  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • Dystonic CP is associated with hypotonia
  • Extrapyramidal CP is associated with ataxia
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV  is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?

choices.text: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue, hyperacusis, loss of lacrimation. Injury is at_____.
questions.solution:
The location of the injury is proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

Injury to greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion.

Injury to nerve to stapedius which is the first motor branch of the facial nerve leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis which can be detected by tympanometry.

Injury to chorda tympani leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.

Since this patient has symptoms of involvement of all 3 nerves the lesion is proximal to the first branch. Hence proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTIs is suspected to have a congenital renal anomaly. The following picture is seen on IV urography. Based on these findings, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter. It describes the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC.

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

Note: Bilateral fishhook or J-shaped or hockey stick ureters describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).

questions.text: All of the following belong to secretin family except____
questions.solution:
CCK (Cholecystokinin) belongs to the gastrin family, not the secretin family.

Classification of GI hormones based on structure and function:

  • Gastrin family - Gastrin, Cholecystokinin.
  • Secretin family - Secretin, Glucagon, VIP, GIP.
  • Others - Motilin, Ghrelin, Somatostatin, etc.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Hormones

Related Pearl: Hormones/Paracrines regulating gastrointestinal function

Hormones/Paracrines

Cells

Gastrin

G cells in the stomach (antrum)

CCK

I cells of duodenum and jejunum

Secretin

S cells deep in the mucosa of upper small intestine

GIP

K cells in mucosa of duodenum and jejunum

Somatostatin

D cells of pancreatic islets

Glucagon

A cells of pancreatic islets

Motilin

Enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in stomach, small intestine, and colon

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing tortuous swelling over the scalp and the clinical findings are suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascuar occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. Moreover, decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted.  Treatment of choice for this patient's condition is?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also called Guangdong tumor.
  • Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. (V more than VI)
    • Headache
    • Earache
    • Neck pain
    • Weight loss

 Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, productive cough, and weight loss. He gives a history of not having completed treatment for tuberculosis thrice in the past. Extensively drug-resistant TB is suspected. How is this entity defined?

choices.text: Resistance to INH + Amikacin + Ofloxacin + Ethambutol
Resistance to INH + Rifampicin + Ofloxacin + Linezolid

questions.solution:
XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug resistant  TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) AND resistant to atleast one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

H: Isoniazid

Hh: High Dose Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: All of these are antigen presenting cells (APC’s) except _____
questions.solution:
T cell is not an antigen-presenting cell. The antigens are presented by antigen presenting cells to T-cell.

Examples of antigen presenting cells: 

  • Dendritic cells
  • Macrophage
  • B cells
  • Glial cells (brain)
  • Fibroblasts (skin)
  • Pancreatic beta-cell
  • Thymic epithelial cells
  • Vascular endothelial cells
  • Thyroid epithelial cells

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-specific history of malaise. Mild sensorineural hearing loss had been diagnosed during his early education, although hearing aids were not required. He gives a history of recurrent hematuria and current investigations reveal the same. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Alport syndrome is a cause of recurrent hematuria, which is associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

 Other causes of recurrent hematuria

  • Alport syndrome
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Papillary necrosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: What is the sign represented by the image below called?
questions.solution:
The above image indicates the presence of Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm in patients experiencing hypocalcemia.

  • To elicit the sign, a blood pressure cuff is placed around the arm, inflated to a pressure greater than the systolic blood pressure, and held in place for 3 minutes.
  • This will occlude the brachial artery.
  • In the absence of blood flow, the patient's condition of hypocalcemia and subsequent neuromuscular irritability will induce spasm of the muscles of the hand and forearm.
  • This sign is also known as main d'accoucheur (French word for "hand of the obstetrician") because it supposedly resembles the position of an obstetrician's hand while delivering a baby.

Other options

Chvostek's sign

  • Seen in hypocalcemia
  • When the facial nerve is tapped in front of the tragus, the facial muscles on the same side of the face will contract momentarily (typically a twitch of the nose or lips) because of hypocalcemia.

Troisier's sign

  • Associated with left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal malignancy.

Lhermitte’s sign

  • Barber chair phenomenon - Electric shock-like sensation upon flexion of the neck observed, involving the posterior column.
  • Classically seen in association with multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male smoker develops severe chest pain. He is diagnosed with MI based on his electrocardiogram and serial CK-MB levels. One week later, he again experiences precordial pain and develops a fever of 101.5°F. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction rub. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests post-myocardial infarction fibrinous pericarditis.

Fibrinous Pericarditis:

  • Most frequent type of pericarditis
  • Seen following myocardial infarct, rheumatic fever, trauma, uremia, radiation, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), severe pneumonia
  • Clinically: loud pericardial friction rub
  • Rubbery fibrin mass loosely glueing the parietal and visceral pericardium together (“bread and butter”)
  • May resolve or become organized to produce an adhesive pericarditis

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Identify the instrument commonly used in obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Episiotomy scissor

The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetretic anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Vaginal mucosa
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles.
  • Internal pudendal blood vessels
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the lady should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for her?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from rapid cycling bipolar disorder. Lithium is used to treat this condition.

Diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year
  • Episodes either have a partial or full remission for atleast 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management in bipolar disorder. It decreases the rate of suicide and is also used in depression with inadequate response to monotherapy and cases of recurrent depression.

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades: 

Grade

Sr. lithium concentration (in mEq/L)

 Symptoms
Mild symptoms 1.5-2.5  nausea, vomiting, tremor, and fatigue
Moderate intoxication 2.5-3.5  confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia
Severe intoxication >3.5  coma, seizures, hyperthermia, and hypotension

Treatment options include gastric lavage and whole bowel irrigation for patients presenting early to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is done for patients demonstrating any signs and symptoms of severe lithium poisoning.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: You receive a dental report from an autopsy of a homicide case, stating that FDI notation tooth number '43' is missing. Which tooth is missing in the victim?
questions.solution:
In FDI notation 43, the number 4 indicates the lower right quadrant and the number 3 indicates canine tooth. Hence 43 indicates the lower right canine.

FDI (Federation Dentaire Internationale) represents a number is assigned to each quadrant and that number is placed before tooth's number.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis).

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gall stone induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the investigation of choice. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

 Balthazar Score

Balthazar Grade

Appearance on CT

CT Grade Points

Grade A

Normal CT

  0 Points
 

Grade B

 Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas  1 Point
 

Grade C

 Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation   2 Points

Grade D

 		 Fluid collection in a single location  3 Points
 

Grade E

 Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas  4 Points
Necrosis Score  

Necrosis Percentage

  

Points

No necrosis

    

0 Points

 
 

0 to 30% necrosis

    

2 Points

 
 

30 to 50% necrosis

  

4 Points

 

 
 

Over 50% necrosis

    6 Points

 

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points.
